items.title: I can identify the components of a chemical formula
items.what: Chemical formulas contain chemical symbols for elements and subscript numbers showing how many atoms of each element are present. If there is only one atom, no subscript is written.
items.why: Reading chemical formulas correctly is essential for understanding what substances are made of and how they react with each other.
items.example: In H₂O, the H represents hydrogen, the subscript 2 means there are two hydrogen atoms, and O represents one oxygen atom. So water contains 2 hydrogen atoms and 1 oxygen atom.

subtopic.name: Chemical Formulas
subtopic.what: Chemical formulas use symbols and numbers to describe the atoms that make up compounds. They show which elements are present and how many atoms of each element are in a molecule or repeating unit of a lattice.
subtopic.why: Understanding chemical formulas allows you to communicate precisely about substances and predict how they will behave in reactions. This is the foundation for reading and writing chemical equations.

items.title: I can distinguish between ionic and covalent compounds
items.what: Ionic compounds are made of metals and non-metals, formed when atoms transfer electrons. Covalent compounds are made of non-metals only, formed when atoms share electrons.
items.why: Knowing whether a compound is ionic or covalent determines how you name it and write its formula, since they follow different rules.
items.example: NaCl (sodium chloride) is ionic because sodium is a metal and chlorine is a non-metal. CO₂ (carbon dioxide) is covalent because both carbon and oxygen are non-metals.

subtopic.name: Chemical Formulas
subtopic.what: Chemical formulas use symbols and numbers to describe the atoms that make up compounds. They show which elements are present and how many atoms of each element are in a molecule or repeating unit of a lattice.
subtopic.why: Understanding chemical formulas allows you to communicate precisely about substances and predict how they will behave in reactions. This is the foundation for reading and writing chemical equations.

items.title: I can write chemical formulas for ionic compounds
items.what: Ionic compound formulas are determined by balancing the positive and negative charges of the ions so the overall compound is neutral. The metal ion is written first, followed by the non-metal ion.
items.why: Writing correct ionic formulas is necessary for representing chemical reactions accurately and predicting the products of reactions.
items.example: Calcium has a 2+ charge and chlorine has a 1- charge. To balance, you need two chloride ions for every calcium ion, giving the formula CaCl₂.

subtopic.name: Chemical Formulas
subtopic.what: Chemical formulas use symbols and numbers to describe the atoms that make up compounds. They show which elements are present and how many atoms of each element are in a molecule or repeating unit of a lattice.
subtopic.why: Understanding chemical formulas allows you to communicate precisely about substances and predict how they will behave in reactions. This is the foundation for reading and writing chemical equations.

items.title: I can name ionic compounds from their formulas
items.what: Ionic compounds are named by stating the metal first, then the non-metal with its ending changed to '-ide'. The formula shows which elements are present.
items.why: Converting between names and formulas allows you to communicate about substances using either representation.
items.example: MgCl₂ contains magnesium and chlorine. The name is magnesium chloride (chlorine becomes chloride).

subtopic.name: Chemical Formulas
subtopic.what: Chemical formulas use symbols and numbers to describe the atoms that make up compounds. They show which elements are present and how many atoms of each element are in a molecule or repeating unit of a lattice.
subtopic.why: Understanding chemical formulas allows you to communicate precisely about substances and predict how they will behave in reactions. This is the foundation for reading and writing chemical equations.

items.title: I can write chemical formulas for covalent compounds
items.what: Covalent compound formulas are written using the chemical name, where prefixes indicate the number of atoms. The element further left on the periodic table is written first.
items.why: Multiple covalent compounds can exist with the same elements but different numbers of atoms, so precise formulas distinguish between them.
items.example: Carbon monoxide has the formula CO (mono- means one oxygen). Carbon dioxide has the formula CO₂ (di- means two oxygens).

subtopic.name: Chemical Formulas
subtopic.what: Chemical formulas use symbols and numbers to describe the atoms that make up compounds. They show which elements are present and how many atoms of each element are in a molecule or repeating unit of a lattice.
subtopic.why: Understanding chemical formulas allows you to communicate precisely about substances and predict how they will behave in reactions. This is the foundation for reading and writing chemical equations.

items.title: I can name covalent compounds using prefixes
items.what: Covalent compounds use prefixes to show the number of atoms: mono- (1), di- (2), tri- (3), tetra- (4), penta- (5), hexa- (6). The prefix mono- is not used for the first element.
items.why: Prefixes distinguish between different compounds made of the same elements, such as nitrogen monoxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO₂).
items.example: N₂O₄ has two nitrogen atoms and four oxygen atoms, so it is named dinitrogen tetroxide.

subtopic.name: Chemical Formulas
subtopic.what: Chemical formulas use symbols and numbers to describe the atoms that make up compounds. They show which elements are present and how many atoms of each element are in a molecule or repeating unit of a lattice.
subtopic.why: Understanding chemical formulas allows you to communicate precisely about substances and predict how they will behave in reactions. This is the foundation for reading and writing chemical equations.

items.title: I can distinguish between physical and chemical changes
items.what: Physical changes alter appearance or state but keep the same substances. Chemical changes (reactions) produce entirely new substances with different properties.
items.why: Recognising whether a change is physical or chemical helps predict whether the original substances can be recovered and what properties the result will have.
items.example: Melting ice is a physical change because the water molecules stay the same. Burning wood is a chemical change because the wood reacts with oxygen to form new substances like carbon dioxide and ash.

subtopic.name: What are Chemical Reactions
subtopic.what: A chemical reaction is the transformation of one or more substances into new substances through the rearrangement of atoms. Chemical bonds are broken and new bonds are formed, but no atoms are created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Chemical reactions are everywhere in daily life, from cooking food to burning fuel to digesting nutrients. Understanding reactions helps explain how and why these changes occur.

items.title: I can identify reactants and products in a chemical reaction
items.what: Reactants are the starting substances that react together. Products are the new substances formed by the reaction. The arrow in an equation means 'produces' or 'yields'.
items.why: Identifying reactants and products is essential for understanding what goes into a reaction and what comes out of it.
items.example: In the reaction: magnesium + oxygen → magnesium oxide, the reactants are magnesium and oxygen, and the product is magnesium oxide.

subtopic.name: What are Chemical Reactions
subtopic.what: A chemical reaction is the transformation of one or more substances into new substances through the rearrangement of atoms. Chemical bonds are broken and new bonds are formed, but no atoms are created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Chemical reactions are everywhere in daily life, from cooking food to burning fuel to digesting nutrients. Understanding reactions helps explain how and why these changes occur.

items.title: I can classify substances as elements or compounds
items.what: Elements contain only one type of atom (like oxygen O₂ or iron Fe). Compounds contain two or more different types of atoms bonded together (like water H₂O or carbon dioxide CO₂).
items.why: Knowing whether substances are elements or compounds helps you understand what happens during reactions and predict possible products.
items.example: Hydrogen gas (H₂) is an element because it contains only hydrogen atoms. Sodium chloride (NaCl) is a compound because it contains both sodium and chlorine atoms.

subtopic.name: What are Chemical Reactions
subtopic.what: A chemical reaction is the transformation of one or more substances into new substances through the rearrangement of atoms. Chemical bonds are broken and new bonds are formed, but no atoms are created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Chemical reactions are everywhere in daily life, from cooking food to burning fuel to digesting nutrients. Understanding reactions helps explain how and why these changes occur.

items.title: I can explain how atoms are rearranged during a chemical reaction
items.what: During a reaction, chemical bonds between atoms are broken and new bonds form in different arrangements. The same atoms are present before and after, just connected differently.
items.why: Understanding atomic rearrangement explains why new substances form and why the total amount of matter stays the same.
items.example: When nitrogen (N₂) and oxygen (O₂) react during a lightning strike, the bonds in N₂ and O₂ break, and the atoms recombine to form nitrogen oxide (NO). The nitrogen and oxygen atoms are rearranged but not created or destroyed.

subtopic.name: What are Chemical Reactions
subtopic.what: A chemical reaction is the transformation of one or more substances into new substances through the rearrangement of atoms. Chemical bonds are broken and new bonds are formed, but no atoms are created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Chemical reactions are everywhere in daily life, from cooking food to burning fuel to digesting nutrients. Understanding reactions helps explain how and why these changes occur.

items.title: I can recognise signs that a chemical reaction has occurred
items.what: Common signs of chemical reactions include colour change, gas production (bubbles), temperature change, light or sound production, and formation of a precipitate (solid).
items.why: Recognising these signs helps you identify when a chemical reaction is happening in experiments or everyday situations.
items.example: When vinegar reacts with baking soda, bubbles form (gas production) and the mixture fizzes. This indicates a chemical reaction is occurring, producing carbon dioxide gas.

subtopic.name: What are Chemical Reactions
subtopic.what: A chemical reaction is the transformation of one or more substances into new substances through the rearrangement of atoms. Chemical bonds are broken and new bonds are formed, but no atoms are created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Chemical reactions are everywhere in daily life, from cooking food to burning fuel to digesting nutrients. Understanding reactions helps explain how and why these changes occur.

items.title: I can write word equations for chemical reactions
items.what: Word equations show reactants on the left, an arrow meaning 'produces', and products on the right. Multiple reactants or products are separated by plus signs.
items.why: Word equations are a simple way to describe reactions in plain language before moving to more detailed symbol equations.
items.example: For the reaction of sodium with oxygen: sodium + oxygen → sodium oxide. The arrow shows that sodium and oxygen react to produce sodium oxide.

subtopic.name: Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Chemical equations represent reactions using either words (word equations) or chemical symbols and formulas (symbol equations). They show what reacts and what is produced.
subtopic.why: Chemical equations are the language scientists use to communicate precisely about reactions. They allow you to see exactly which elements are involved and in what amounts.

items.title: I can convert word equations to symbol equations
items.what: Symbol equations replace substance names with their chemical formulas. This shows exactly which elements are present and how many atoms of each are in the compounds.
items.why: Symbol equations provide more information than word equations, showing the exact composition of all substances involved.
items.example: The word equation 'hydrogen + oxygen → water' becomes the symbol equation 'H₂ + O₂ → H₂O'. This shows that hydrogen and oxygen molecules combine to form water molecules.

subtopic.name: Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Chemical equations represent reactions using either words (word equations) or chemical symbols and formulas (symbol equations). They show what reacts and what is produced.
subtopic.why: Chemical equations are the language scientists use to communicate precisely about reactions. They allow you to see exactly which elements are involved and in what amounts.

items.title: I can interpret chemical formulas in equations
items.what: In symbol equations, subscripts show atoms within a molecule and coefficients (numbers in front) show how many molecules are involved. To find total atoms, multiply coefficient by subscript.
items.why: Correctly counting atoms is essential for understanding reactions and checking whether equations are balanced.
items.example: In 2H₂O, the coefficient 2 means two water molecules. Each water molecule has 2 hydrogen atoms, so total hydrogen = 2 × 2 = 4 atoms. Total oxygen = 2 × 1 = 2 atoms.

subtopic.name: Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Chemical equations represent reactions using either words (word equations) or chemical symbols and formulas (symbol equations). They show what reacts and what is produced.
subtopic.why: Chemical equations are the language scientists use to communicate precisely about reactions. They allow you to see exactly which elements are involved and in what amounts.

items.title: I can use state symbols in chemical equations
items.what: State symbols show the physical state of each substance: (s) for solid, (l) for liquid, (g) for gas, and (aq) for aqueous (dissolved in water).
items.why: State symbols provide important information about the conditions of a reaction and the physical form of reactants and products.
items.example: AgNO₃(aq) + NaCl(aq) → AgCl(s) + NaNO₃(aq) shows that silver nitrate and sodium chloride solutions react to form solid silver chloride and sodium nitrate solution.

subtopic.name: Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Chemical equations represent reactions using either words (word equations) or chemical symbols and formulas (symbol equations). They show what reacts and what is produced.
subtopic.why: Chemical equations are the language scientists use to communicate precisely about reactions. They allow you to see exactly which elements are involved and in what amounts.

items.title: I can explain the difference between coefficients and subscripts
items.what: Subscripts are part of the chemical formula and show atoms within a single molecule. Coefficients are placed before formulas and show how many molecules are present. Only coefficients can be changed when balancing.
items.why: Changing subscripts would create different substances, while changing coefficients just changes the amount of each substance.
items.example: H₂O and H₂O₂ are completely different substances (water vs hydrogen peroxide). But 2H₂O just means two water molecules instead of one.

subtopic.name: Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Chemical equations represent reactions using either words (word equations) or chemical symbols and formulas (symbol equations). They show what reacts and what is produced.
subtopic.why: Chemical equations are the language scientists use to communicate precisely about reactions. They allow you to see exactly which elements are involved and in what amounts.

items.title: I can state the law of conservation of matter
items.what: The law of conservation of matter states that in any chemical reaction, the total number of atoms of each element remains the same. Atoms are rearranged but never created or destroyed.
items.why: This fundamental law explains why chemical equations must be balanced and why mass is conserved in reactions.
items.example: If a reaction starts with 4 carbon atoms and 12 hydrogen atoms, the products must also contain exactly 4 carbon atoms and 12 hydrogen atoms, just arranged differently.

subtopic.name: Balancing Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Balancing equations means adjusting coefficients so that the number of atoms of each element is equal on both sides. This reflects the law of conservation of matter, which states that atoms cannot be created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Balanced equations accurately represent what happens in real reactions. They are needed to calculate quantities of reactants and products.

items.title: I can determine whether a chemical equation is balanced or unbalanced
items.what: An equation is balanced if the number of atoms of each element is the same on both sides. Count atoms by multiplying coefficients by subscripts for each element.
items.why: Checking if equations are balanced helps verify that they correctly represent the reaction according to conservation of matter.
items.example: In Fe₂O₃ + Al → Fe + Al₂O₃, the left side has 2 Fe and the right side has 1 Fe. The equation is unbalanced because iron atoms are not equal on both sides.

subtopic.name: Balancing Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Balancing equations means adjusting coefficients so that the number of atoms of each element is equal on both sides. This reflects the law of conservation of matter, which states that atoms cannot be created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Balanced equations accurately represent what happens in real reactions. They are needed to calculate quantities of reactants and products.

items.title: I can balance simple chemical equations by adjusting coefficients
items.what: To balance an equation, add coefficients in front of formulas until each element has equal atoms on both sides. Never change subscripts, as this would change the substances.
items.why: Balancing equations is a core chemistry skill needed for calculating reaction quantities and predicting products.
items.example: To balance H₂ + O₂ → H₂O: Start with 2 H and 2 O on the left, but only 2 H and 1 O on the right. Add coefficient 2 before H₂O to get 4 H and 2 O. Then add 2 before H₂: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O.

subtopic.name: Balancing Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Balancing equations means adjusting coefficients so that the number of atoms of each element is equal on both sides. This reflects the law of conservation of matter, which states that atoms cannot be created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Balanced equations accurately represent what happens in real reactions. They are needed to calculate quantities of reactants and products.

items.title: I can balance more complex equations systematically
items.what: For complex equations, balance one element at a time, often starting with elements that appear in only one compound on each side. Check and adjust until all elements are balanced.
items.why: A systematic approach helps solve equations that cannot be balanced by trial and error alone.
items.example: For CH₄ + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O: Balance C first (1 on each side). Balance H next: 4 H on left needs 2H₂O on right. Balance O last: 2 O in CO₂ + 2 O in 2H₂O = 4 O total, so need 2O₂. Final: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O.

subtopic.name: Balancing Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Balancing equations means adjusting coefficients so that the number of atoms of each element is equal on both sides. This reflects the law of conservation of matter, which states that atoms cannot be created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Balanced equations accurately represent what happens in real reactions. They are needed to calculate quantities of reactants and products.

items.title: I can explain why coefficients can be changed but subscripts cannot
items.what: Coefficients show how many molecules are present and can be adjusted freely. Subscripts define the chemical formula of each substance and changing them would create different substances.
items.why: Understanding this distinction prevents errors in balancing and ensures equations represent the actual substances involved.
items.example: Changing H₂O to H₂O₂ would change water into hydrogen peroxide, a completely different chemical. But changing H₂O to 2H₂O just means two water molecules, which is valid for balancing.

subtopic.name: Balancing Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Balancing equations means adjusting coefficients so that the number of atoms of each element is equal on both sides. This reflects the law of conservation of matter, which states that atoms cannot be created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Balanced equations accurately represent what happens in real reactions. They are needed to calculate quantities of reactants and products.

items.title: I can verify that a balanced equation follows conservation of matter
items.what: After balancing, count all atoms of each element on both sides to confirm they are equal. This verifies the equation follows the law of conservation of matter.
items.why: Verification ensures accuracy and builds confidence that the balanced equation correctly represents the reaction.
items.example: For 2Na + Cl₂ → 2NaCl: Left side has 2 Na and 2 Cl. Right side has 2 Na (in 2NaCl) and 2 Cl (in 2NaCl). Both elements are equal, so the equation is correctly balanced.

subtopic.name: Balancing Chemical Equations
subtopic.what: Balancing equations means adjusting coefficients so that the number of atoms of each element is equal on both sides. This reflects the law of conservation of matter, which states that atoms cannot be created or destroyed.
subtopic.why: Balanced equations accurately represent what happens in real reactions. They are needed to calculate quantities of reactants and products.

items.title: I can distinguish between open and closed systems
items.what: A closed system only allows heat transfer with the environment, keeping all matter inside. An open system allows both heat and matter to transfer with the surroundings.
items.why: The type of system affects whether mass changes are observed during a reaction, even though matter is always conserved.
items.example: A sealed container with reacting chemicals is a closed system. A beaker open to the air is an open system where gases can escape or enter.

subtopic.name: Conservation of Matter
subtopic.what: The law of conservation of matter can be demonstrated through experiments that measure mass before and after chemical reactions. In a closed system, total mass remains constant even though substances change.
subtopic.why: Experimental evidence supports the law of conservation of matter and helps explain observations that might otherwise seem contradictory, such as apparent mass changes in open systems.

items.title: I can predict mass changes in open and closed systems
items.what: In a closed system, total mass stays constant during a reaction. In an open system, mass may appear to change if gases escape or enter, but matter is still conserved overall.
items.why: Understanding system types explains why mass measurements can differ and why conservation of matter still holds true.
items.example: When baking soda reacts with vinegar in a sealed container, the mass stays the same. In an open container, the mass decreases because carbon dioxide gas escapes into the air.

subtopic.name: Conservation of Matter
subtopic.what: The law of conservation of matter can be demonstrated through experiments that measure mass before and after chemical reactions. In a closed system, total mass remains constant even though substances change.
subtopic.why: Experimental evidence supports the law of conservation of matter and helps explain observations that might otherwise seem contradictory, such as apparent mass changes in open systems.

items.title: I can explain why burning objects appear to lose mass
items.what: When substances burn in open air, gaseous products escape into the atmosphere. The solid remains weigh less, but the total mass of all products (including gases) equals the original mass.
items.why: This explains everyday observations like wood turning to ash and appearing lighter, while confirming that matter is never actually destroyed.
items.example: When charcoal burns, it reacts with oxygen to form carbon dioxide gas. The charcoal appears to lose mass because the CO₂ escapes. If you could capture and weigh all the CO₂, the total mass would be unchanged.

subtopic.name: Conservation of Matter
subtopic.what: The law of conservation of matter can be demonstrated through experiments that measure mass before and after chemical reactions. In a closed system, total mass remains constant even though substances change.
subtopic.why: Experimental evidence supports the law of conservation of matter and helps explain observations that might otherwise seem contradictory, such as apparent mass changes in open systems.

items.title: I can explain why some reactions cause mass to increase
items.what: When substances react with gases from the air (like oxygen), the solid products may gain mass because atoms from the gas become part of the new substance.
items.why: This demonstrates that matter from the surroundings can be incorporated into products, following conservation of matter.
items.example: When steel wool burns, it reacts with oxygen from the air to form iron oxide. The iron oxide weighs more than the original steel wool because it now contains oxygen atoms that came from the air.

subtopic.name: Conservation of Matter
subtopic.what: The law of conservation of matter can be demonstrated through experiments that measure mass before and after chemical reactions. In a closed system, total mass remains constant even though substances change.
subtopic.why: Experimental evidence supports the law of conservation of matter and helps explain observations that might otherwise seem contradictory, such as apparent mass changes in open systems.

items.title: I can use models to demonstrate conservation of atoms in reactions
items.what: Physical models like ball-and-stick kits show how atoms from reactant molecules are rearranged to form product molecules. The same atoms appear on both sides, just connected differently.
items.why: Models make the abstract concept of atomic rearrangement visible and concrete, reinforcing understanding of conservation.
items.example: Using coloured balls for atoms: to model N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃, you start with 2 blue nitrogen balls bonded together and 6 white hydrogen balls in 3 pairs. You rearrange them into 2 ammonia molecules, each with 1 nitrogen and 3 hydrogens.

subtopic.name: Conservation of Matter
subtopic.what: The law of conservation of matter can be demonstrated through experiments that measure mass before and after chemical reactions. In a closed system, total mass remains constant even though substances change.
subtopic.why: Experimental evidence supports the law of conservation of matter and helps explain observations that might otherwise seem contradictory, such as apparent mass changes in open systems.

items.title: I can design experiments to demonstrate conservation of matter
items.what: To demonstrate conservation of matter, measure the total mass before and after a reaction in a closed system. Any mass difference indicates gases escaped or the system was not fully closed.
items.why: Experimental skills allow you to test scientific laws and understand sources of error in measurements.
items.example: Place baking soda and vinegar in a sealed plastic container on a balance. Record the mass, then tip the container to mix them. After the reaction stops, the mass reading should be the same as before (or very close, if some gas escaped).
